misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes arrays in Java are indexed starting at 1, so they use indices 1..N to fill and search the array, and assume index N is valid.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0..N-1. Accessing arr_nums[N] is out of bounds and will throw an exception before the program can produce the required output. Also, even if it didn't crash, the reported index would be shifted by +1 compared to the required 0-based index.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during input and/or search; incorrect index reporting if bounds were adjusted incorrectly.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java start at 1, just like counting in natural language. When creating an array and iterating through it, the student thinks the first element should be accessed at index 1, not index 0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are zero-indexed, meaning valid indices range from 0 to N-1. The student has confused the size of the array (N) with the valid index range. When iterating with `for (int i = 1; i <= N; i++)`, the loop attempts to access arr_nums[N], which is out of bounds, and never accesses arr_nums[0], where the first input element is actually stored.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when trying to populate the array, or if that somehow succeeded, the search would skip the first element and potentially access invalid memory, producing incorrect results or crashes.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array elements are indexed starting from 1 up to the length of the array inclusive, similar to how one counts objects in real life.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing. For an array of size N, valid indices range from 0 to N-1. The student attempts to access index N, which is out of bounds, and ignores index 0.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: 1-based indexing assumption for Java arrays (off-by-one bounds)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 and that an array of size N has valid positions 1 through N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: an array of length N has valid indices 0 through N-1. Using indices 1..N skips index 0 and attempts to access index N, which is out of bounds and causes a runtime exception.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) during input loop (and also during search loop if it got that far).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java start from 1, similar to arrays in some other programming languages like MATLAB or FORTRAN. They assume that an array of size N has valid indices from 1 to N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. An array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. The student's loop starting at i=1 and ending at i<=N attempts to access arr_nums[N], which is out of bounds and will cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException. Additionally, the first element at arr_nums[0] is never populated or searched.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when the input loop tries to access arr_nums[N], which is beyond the valid range of the array. Even if the array access didn't crash, the logic would skip the first element and return incorrect indices.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays use 1-based indexing, where the first element is stored at index 1 and the final element is stored at index N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed. For an array of size N, the valid indices range from 0 to N-1. Starting at 1 and including N in the loop results in skipping the first element (index 0) and triggering a runtime ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when the counter reaching N.
